channel.title: Mike Gleicher's Talks on Michael Gleicher's Web Page
channel.description: Recent content in Mike Gleicher's Talks on Michael Gleicher's Web Page

item.title: Interpretting Embeddings With Comparison
item.description: Invited Keynote at the CSIG-VIS International Lecture Series (China, virtual). A recording of the talk is available at: https://www.bilibili.com/video/BV1Hv411u7c6 Interpreting Embeddings with Comparison from gleicher

item.title: Dumb Robots for Smart People
item.description: Invited Keynote at the AI-HRI Symposium (AAAI Fall Symposium Series) Dumb Robots for Smart People (Direct Control Interfaces for Robotics) from gleicher

item.title: Interpreting Embeddings with Comparison
item.description: Invited talk at the Computer Science Department Seminar, University of Arizona, Tuscon, January 15, 2019.

item.title: What Shakespeare Taught Us About Visualization and Data Science
item.description: Invited talk at the TRIPODS (Data Science) Seminar, University of Arizona, Tuscon, January 14, 2019. This talk is similar to the previous talk of the same title.

item.title: Interactive Analysis of Word Vector Embeddings
item.description: Paper presentation at EuroVis 2018

item.title: Perception, Comparison, and Models for Uncertainty
item.description: Invited talk at the EuroRV^3 Uncertainty workshop

item.title: What Shakespeare Taught Us About Visualization and Data Science
item.description: Invited talk at the University of Vienna, May 30, 2018. This talk is similar to the previous talk of the same title.

item.title: Considerations for Visualizing Comparisons

item.description: Invited keynote at the IEEE Professional Communications Society Meeting

item.title: Through the Lens of 25 Years: Through-the-Lens Camera Control Revisited
item.description: Invited Keynote at WICED 2017 (6th Workshop on Intelligent Cinematography and Editing), Lyon, France.

item.title: What Shakespeare Taught Us About Data Science and Visualization
item.description: Seminar at Johns Hopkins University, December 2016. A similar talk was given at New York University in October.

item.title: Towards Comprehensible Modeling (Human-Centric Issues in Data Analytics)
item.description: Talk at the Midwest Big Data Workshop at the University of Chicago.

item.title: Visualization (Tutorial at EMDA)
item.description: An invited tutorial on Visualization at the Early Modern Digital Agendas workshop at the Folger Library, Washington, DC. 1 - Intro 2 - What is Visualization? 3 - Encodings

item.title: Seeing, Scatterplots and Shakespeare
item.description: Invited talk at Portland State University, May 2015. This talk is an update of the earlier talk with a similar title.

item.title: Towards Comprehensible Predictive Modeling
item.description: Talk at the VisWeek 2014 Workshop on Visualization for Predictive Analytics

item.title: Towards Comprehensible Modeling
item.description: Talk at the Dagstuhl Seminar “Scientific Visualization”, June 2, 2014

item.title: Seeing, Scatterplots and Shakespeare: Adventures in Data Visualization
item.description: Talk given at the Journ√©e scientifique de l’ARC 6 in Grenoble. This was a meeting of researchers from various fields from around the Rhone-Alpes region. (slides 9-up) This talk was also given at the Technische Universitat Wien (Vienna, Austria, December 2013) and INRAI-Saclay (near Paris, February 2014), with very similar slides.

item.title: Explainers: Expert Explorations with Crafted Projections
item.description: Talk given at VIS 2013 conference for a VAST (TVCG) paper.

item.title: Splatterplots: Overcoming Overdraw in Scatter Plots
item.description: Talk given at VIS 2013 conference for a TVCG journal paper.

item.title: Why Evaluate?
item.description: Presentation at the BELIV ‘12 workshop (tag team presentation with Miriah, based on conversations with Michael Sedlmair.

item.title: from Art and Perception to Visualization, Video, and Virtual Reality
item.description: Talk given at INRIA Rhone-Alps (Grenoble, FR) and INRIA Sophia Antipolis (Sophia-Antipolis, FR).

item.title: Seeing Shakespeare (and Sequences): Making pictures to learn from stuff you don't want to read
item.description: A talk given at Memorial Library as part of the Humanities Research Bridge.

item.title: From Art and Perception to Visualization and Video
item.description: A talk at the CMU Robotics seminar. A video of the talk is on YouTube (availble in HD)!

item.title: Pictures from Piles of Data: How Graphics, Multimedia, Vision, Visualization, Animation and Cartography All Connect
item.description: A Talk at the Institute for Mathematics and its Applications (IMA) at the University of Minnesota.

item.title: Using Perception to Make Better Pictures
item.description: A Talk at the ERI seminar, University of Wisconsin, Madison (note, this is a shortened version of the Pictures from Piles of Data talk)

item.description: A Talk at the Chaos and Complexity seminar, University of Wisconsin, Madison

item.description: A talk at The Hacker Within monthly meeting.

item.title: Motion Synthesis by Example: Data-Centric Approches for Animating Game Characters
item.description: Distinguished Lecture at the University of Utah Computer Sciences Department. Note: because of the slide animation, some of this doesn’t look so great in print form.

item.title: Synthesis by Example: Connecting Motion Planning and Example-Based Movement
item.description: Presentation at SIGGRAPH 2008 course “Motion Planning and Autonomy for Virtual Humans.”

item.title: More Motion Capture* in Games: Can we make example-based approaches scale
item.description: Presentation at the Motion in Games Workshop, Utrecht, June 2008.

item.title: Re-Cinematography: Improving the Camera Dynamics of Casual Video
item.description: Presentation at ACM Multimedia 2007 in the Best Papers Session.

item.title: Human Motion Synthesis by Example
item.description: A Talk Given at the Game Technologies Seminar. This is really the first part of a tag-team talk given with Lucas. Originally it was scheduled for a longer period of time, so most of the slides were skipped in order to cram it into 75 minutes.

item.title: Animation by Example
item.description: An overview talk given at both Seoul National University and KAIST (Korean Advanced Institute for Science and Technology).

item.title: Animation by Example 1: Introduction and Motion Representation
item.description: Lecture given at the Workshop on Image Processing and Related Issues at Zhejiang University. This lecture was the first 2 parts of 5 (it was given as a 2 hour lecture with a break in the middle).

item.title: Animation by Example 2: Motion Signal Processing
item.description: Lecture given at the Workshop on Image Processing and Related Issues at Zheziang University. This lecture was the 3 part of 5.

item.title: Animation by Example 4: Concatenative Approaches
item.description: Lecture given at the Workshop on Image Processing and Related Issues at Zhejiang University. This lecture was part 4 of 5.

item.title: Animation by Example 5: Parametric Methods
item.description: Lecture given at the Workshop on Image Processing and Related Issues at Zhejiang University. This lecture was part 5 of 5.

item.title: Imaging and Visualizing Microvascular Architecture
item.description: Seminar presented at the CIBM seminar series, November 11, 2003. Talk split with co-PI Garet Lahvis.

item.title: Human Animation for Interactive Systems
item.description: This is a talk given at the University of Texas, Austin and at Sony (August 2003).

item.title: Animation By Example
item.description: Seminar presented various places (including Illinois, IBM, Stanford, Pixar, Michigan, Penn)

item.description: Talk for the CS Club to introduce what we do at Wisconsin.
